title: `Failed to write block into disk: input/output error` roll back without full resync?
body:
Our Goerli geth node ran into a I/O error and is stuck around the block `7,314,055`.

I tried running a `debug.setHead(7250000)` but it takes too long and the node fails before serving the request (in around 7 mins). Hence the really large number of unclean shutdowns in the logs.

Added the logs below. How can I roll back the chain without a complete resync?

Also, it seems our disk is starting to degrade cc: @ligi 

#### System information

Geth version: `1.10.20` (actually a fork that writes contract creation codes into an SQL DB: https://github.com/sourcifyeth/go-ethereum )
OS & Version: Linux

Run command: `geth --syncmode full --snapshot=false --goerli --http --http.api personal,eth,net,web3,debug --http.addr 0.0.0.0 --http.corsdomain '*'`


#### Expected behaviour

Continued syncing

#### Actual behaviour

Failure with `CRIT [08-04|15:49:09.715] Failed to write block into disk          err="read /root/.ethereum/goerli/geth/chaindata/711530.ldb: input/output error"` and restart since the Docker container is configured to `restart: always`.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

pretty sure this will need a resync - don't think there is anything geth can do here ..

`input/output error` is thrown by OS. 

> This is something that does happen once in a while: when you connect an external storage device to a desktop computer or laptop, it appears to be inaccessible. As a result, the operating system shows a message about an input / output error in your device.

Do you use the external storage device?
My guess is that your disk is full

No it's a mounted disk afaik. It seems the SSD disk is degrading and therefore the error. 

The question is if it is possible to recover without fully deleting the chaindata and doing a complete sync. If it is not possible the issue can be closed.
@kuzdogan You can try to rerun the Geth and to see if it can recover.

If there was error writing a leveldb file, I'd imagine there could be faults even before that got silently missed. You can definitely copy your datadir to a new disk and try if it recovers. If it does, you might want to also check that your state is not corrupted:

```
$ geth snapshot traverse-rawstate
$ geth snapshot verify-state
```

This should give a high enough confidence that the database is ok, though it won't be absolutely perfect.
